text:
Made this recipe twice....both times I thought this was a great mac n cheese.  I did add 1/2-3/4 cup milk and did throw in 1/2 bag of shredded velveeta.  Also, I used Ritz crackers instead of the breadcrumbs, sprinkled some garlic powder in them and added the rest of the shredded velveeta.  Put this combo on the mac n cheese during the last 10 minutes of baking.  Delish!

I made this recipe exactly as it says to and it was ok.  My husband loved it.  I thought that it had too much bread crumbs and not enough cheese, but I think it depends on your taste.  My husband hates velveeta so I could never put that in it.  I am going to make this again though.  I am going to cut down the topping by at least half and I am going to add more cheese. I am going to try processing it in the food processor first like someone else suggested.  I also think I may melt the cheese mixture on the stove first.  This is still a decent recipe though.  It´s all in what you like!

country:
None
text:
I have finally found a mac and cheese recipe that I can make healthy!  This was so easy to alter to keep the fat down and add additional nutrition.  I used whole wheat noodles, low fat cottage cheese and fat free sour cream.  I blended the cottage and cheese and sour cream to gain a better consistancy for picky kids (it came out like ricotta).  Then, I added southwestern seasoning salt, italian seasoning and garlic powder.  I mixed a half a cup of 1% milk to make it creamier.  I used 4 oz of low fat mexican cheese blend, 4 oz of italian cheese blend, and 4 oz of colby jack (I didn't have chedder or parm).  I even added a cauliflower/zuchinni puree to the mix to add a little more nutrition.  The kids didn't know the difference - said it was their favorite mac and cheese!

text:
interesting.  the flavors are good, though i admit i doctored mine up by adding cooked chicken and bacon crumbles, green onions, and garlic pepper.  i also used a combo of sharp and mild cheddar and some mild Monterey jack.  and increased the ratio of pasta (narrow corkscrew shape.) still, the texture of this dish i would call "a noodle casserole with cheese" not my vision of "mac and cheese."  but i was expecting that from reading the other reviews.  for the people who wrote it tasted like "with egg" custard style baked mac and cheese without the egg -i think i'll throw in an egg if i make it again. again, interesting to make if you have the ingredients on hand, but i wouldn't buy stuff just to make this.

text:
I had been craving home made mac and cheese for a few weeks and finally gave in and decided to make it. I came across this recipe and I am SO happy I decided on this one!! I did make a few small modifications for my own tastes: I added about 1/2 cup of peas, I chopped and sauteed one leek with a bit of garlic in EVOO and added that to the mixture at the end which tasted awesome in my opinion! I also subbed in one 12oz block of firm tofu for the cottage cheese because I had some on hand that i wanted to use up and I think that it worked quite well for the consistency. Definitely cut the bread crumbs down to about a 1/4 cup. 

I can't wait to make this again!

text:
This is a keeper! I doubled the recipe to fill a 9x13 casserole dish. I was leary of the cottage cheese (not a fan) but left it in thinking it may be a crucial part of the flavor (though I did run it through a food processor first to eliminate chunks of cottage cheese). This is delicious mac & cheese. A cup of bread crumbs is way too much - it detracts from the flavor of the dish, so next time, I'll only use 1/3 of a cup of bread crumbs. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I am giving this 5 stars even though I did things a little differently.  I didn't have sour cream so didn't use that.  To the rest of the basic recipe, I added 4 finely chopped scallions including the green part, 1 1/2 tsp. dry mustard, 4 or 5 shakes of green tobasco, about 1 cup parmesan freshly grated and a cup of cottage cheese.  I added about a cup of milk. I then sprinkled about 2 TBSP. Ital breadcrumbs on top, and shook some pre made parmesan over that then sprayed with butter pam.  This came out spectacular.  The best mac and cheese I've ever made and I've tried lots of recipes. Thank You!!!

text:
This was absolutely delicious!  However, I think next time I will prepare it without the breadcrumb topping...just a preference.  When I take out the breadcrumb topping, I will probably add 1/2 cup of milk as others said they did, because I imagine without the breadcrumb topping holding the moisture in, it could become a little dry.  Also, I agree with Amy D., better to mix in bowl, and then place in the baking pan because it's easier to mix up.  I really did love it though.  Very tasty!!

This was good, but it does have a very "sharp" taste. I thought it was the sharp cheddar, so the second time I made it, I used mild. Still tasted sharp, so it must be the sour cream. If you want a milder taste, maybe use less sour cream and mix in some milk or something. My husband and I liked it, but it was strong for my son.
Edited to add: The day after, this is even better. The flavor really mellows, and the leftovers are perfect.

I decided to "try something new" and try a different recipe to mix things up a bit and I'm very sorry I did. NOT EVEN CLOSE. I'm sure some may love it but it just wasn't for us. I gave it 2 stars because it was edible but that's about it. 

P.S. I very rarely leave a review on recipes. It has to be pretty darn impressive or very bad to get me to come yap about it. ;)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5734150.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my go-to Mac & cheese. I make it for potlucks and Thanksgiving every year and always get rave reviews and requests to make it again. I do equal parts butter/breadcrumbs (1/4 cup each) and that is plenty. I make the cheese mixture the night before so that all the flavors can meld together and stir in the half cup of milk (as suggested by another reviewer) when I add the cooked noodles the next day. I also always add a little extra salt at this point as well, because of the milk. I taste everything right before it goes in the oven to check for salt/pepper. Fail proof! So good.

text:
After reading many reviews, I was anticipating a delicious dinner. Sorry to say I was sadly disappointed. I also applied the suggestion from many to add milk, as it was dry without the additions liquid. The texture was clumpy, even though I cut back on the cottage cheese, and used my immersion blender to smooth it out prior to mixing. I have been cooking for over 40 years, and am considered to be a great cook. Perhaps the fact that I am from New England has affected my opinion. I have never had mac and cheese with cottage cheese as an ingredient. Mac and cheese in this area has an abundant and creamy sauce. I made it two days ago, and the leftovers haven’t been touched by anyone in my family. A sure sign that this was not a hit at this kitchen. Even two stars is generous.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love love love this mac&cheese! I don't add bread crumbs to mine because I think that's strange but other than that, I follow the recipe exactly. Don't leave out the cottage cheese! It's always the hit of the party in its ooey gooey cheesy goodness. I also like to take this camping with me. Prep it like normal, add additional milk to keep it moist and throw it in a couple gallon ziplock bags. When you're ready to cook, throw your pasta in a foil pie pan (don't forget to grease!!) wrapped with foil and throw it on the fire. Yum yum yum!!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Fantastic mac and cheese.  I modified to double the batch more or less.  I agree with others that this needs a LOT more liquid than it calls for if you want it creamy.  Of course how liquid or not you want it is subjective.  I probably used half the cottage cheese called for, and subbed in quesadilla cheese (very mild, off white Mexican cheese, shredded - found in Wal-mart and IMO THE best shredded cheese on the market for any Mexican or Tex-Mex dish you make).  I also reduced the bread crumbs a bit per other reviews.   Mac and Cheese is hard to mess up, but I've made quite a few and this one by far was best (including slow cooker mac and cheese recipe on here, which had my previous top spot).   Fantastic recipe!   Thanks OP.

text:
I doubled and followed the recipe and used some of the suggestions I found in the reviews.  I used regular sharp and regular parmesan cheeses, low fat cottage cheese, low fat sour cream, and I added 3/4 C skim milk and a few dashes cayenne pepper.  I used 1/4 C melted butter mixed with 1 C panko bread crumbs for the topping.  Everybody loved it, and I sent the recipe out to two friends.  It mades a hearty 9x13 and 8x8 pans.  Thank you Chuck.

text:
I have been making this Mac and cheese for years and it is always a hit among kids and adults. I leave the bread crumbs off completely. I mix cheddar cheese and a little Parmesan cheese with the noodle mixture. On the top, I sprinkle a thin layer of Parmesan cheese which gives it a super cheesy texture and dramatic look when you cut into the meal. Add freshly grated cheddar cheese to the top to cover. 

Easy and perfect every time!!

Display Name:
The Hermanator

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Through a series of events, I ended up with way too much cheese that needed to be used and looking for a way to 'offload it on my coworkers'. I decided this recipe could handle the load, even though I myself am not a mac & cheese fan and had never made any variation of the dish before. The only problem I faced with this recipe is that apparently I did not make enough. Those who got to try it first immediately determined they needed second helpings and, as a result, I have been on the receiving end of some disdainful looks from my slower coworkers all afternoon.
The slight variations I made were using medium shell pasta instead of elbow, adding some Colby jack cheese, a bit of cream cheese, more white cheddar, ½ cup of milk and only ¼ cup of seasoned panko breadcrumbs (per other users' suggestions). Also, I may not have measured everything correctly, as it was a mad dash to fit this into my morning routine – easy as it is. To conclude, I will definitely be making this again, and the only things I would change are making at least double the amount, and maybe ½ cup of the breadcrumbs instead of a ¼. Did I mention I had a second helping myself? Oh well, you can’t please everybody. Sadly, there was no time for a picture.

text:
This was by far one of the easiest to make with the most flavor pay off! I am so used to making  mac and cheese with a bechamel sauce, now I dont have to! I mean granted this isnt as creamy BUT its more like a macaroni pie or bake! I used old cheddar and a ton of parmigean  cheese (make sure to use fresh parm) i also added some cayenne, you dont need much but its nice to cut the richness.  I ended up filling 2 9x13 pans!
oh and I didn't add the breadcrumb crust and it turned out just fine!

This recipe is not bad.  The mac and cheese came out thick.  I would have preferred a more cheesy mac and cheese. text:
If it sounds too good to be true, it usually is.  I thought this recipe sounded really good, quick and easy.  It was way too easy and tasted like it too.  This was definitely NOT the creamy mac n cheese I was hoping for.  I guess I'll have to find a more traditional rue and 5 cheese mac n cheese to satisfy that craving.

This recipe wasn't bad by any means, but it wasn't creamy. It actually was kind of lumpy with the small curd cottage cheese.  And a bit too dry with the amount of bread crumbs that it called for.  I would use less bread crumbs and use a smaller pan than called for so the mac n cheese would be thicker. 9 X 13 is too big for the amount of ingredients.

Off to find that creamy, cheesy mac n cheese that I long for ;-)

Display Name:
Marcia

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7780135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe... an especially good "adult" mac n cheese.  I used Barilla Gluten Free Elbows and substituted crushed corn tortillas for the bread crumbs to make this gluten free, and I used 6 oz colby-jack, 1 oz sharp cheddar and 1 oz Jalapeno-pepper-jack cheeses instead of the 8 oz of cheddar, because that's what I had on hand. I added a few sprinkles of red pepper flakes which, along with the pepper jack cheese, kicked up the flavor a notch.  I sprayed my baking pan with Pam, and even though I mixed the ingredients right in the baking pan, it did not stick.  The cottage cheese did not melt together with the rest of the cheese and sour cream, and the little pieces of cottage cheese were clearly visible in the finished product.  While it's not what I was going for, I'm glad it came out this way because it added a nice texture to the dish.
Review:

5

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have EVERYONE begging me for this recipe! 
I love how easy it is to adjust the portions up or down. 
I usually add 1/4 cup of milk at the suggestion of other reviewers, it truly does keep the leftovers moist the next few days (If it lasts that long!)
I also grate (not chop!) about 1/3 of a small yellow onion into the mix as well as add bacon (I found this recipe to be lacking in salt -- something I almost NEVER say but this trick adds both bacon and salt) a well as doubling the cheddar cheese (I usually use half old white and half extra old orange).

text:
-- I make this for every holiday, birthday party, and get together. I never have leftovers.  There are a few things I do differently. First and foremost, make this in the crockpot!!! The cheese melts better and more thoroughly than in the oven. Second, forget the breadcrumbs. Third, add more sour cream and substitute cottage cheese for cream cheese. Finally, add milk.

text:
I made it almost exactly according to the directions.  I was surprised that it didn't call for milk.  In fear of it turning out too dry,  I poured about 3/4 cup of milk over the top, before adding the breaded topping.  I also doubled the recipe.  I used aluminum foil while baking and removed it the last 5 minutes or so to kinda toast the top.   I didn't use all of the topping the recipe called for either.  It was just overkill for me.  I used all low-fat ingredients including the sour cream and cottage cheese and it turned out great.  Everyone loved it!

text:
Alright alright alright (in my best Matthew McConaughey voice).  

Changes on my end:  I doubled the recipe, divided and baked in two 8x8 Pyrex dishes.   Omitted the Parmesan (but not on purpose) I haven't quite mastered the skill of texting and cooking.  Didn't add salt and didn't add pepper.

My children's taste buds are SO REFINED they know they don't like something before they've even tried it *eye roll* so I couldn't get feedback from them but thumbs up from the picky husband and my sweet (and brutally honest at times) mom.  Not dry AT ALL and I agree with another reviewer that people who are saying that might be dumping in a whole bag of noodles when it only calls for 8oz.

My leaving out the Parmesan probably cut back on the type of additional salt I wanted,  it was already really good but I bet it would have been even better had I not messed that up.   Hooray for homemade Mac & Cheese!!

text:
I made it and thought it was great. I added a half cup of 2% milk, used lite ricotta instead of cottage cheese, and lite sour cream as suggested by many reviewers. I cooked it for 45 minutes before the top started to brown.  I probably could have used more salt and pepper but I still thought it turned out tasty. It wasn't "creamy" or "yellow" like a Kraft dinner type Mac and cheese which some people dig.  I would like it to be a bit creamier so I might try more milk next time. All in all a tasty success on the first try.

region:

country:
None
text:
I've made this multiple time and people are ALWAYS asking me for the recipe afterwards. I do tweak it here and there, sometimes I'll use full fat cheeses and creams, sometimes non-fat versions. If I am making it for my family I add some pepper flakes and garlic. You can doctor this us however you like and it will still be delicious.
EDIT: When making the breadcrumb topping, always use SALTED butter for a little extra flavor! I sprinkle extra cheese on top before putting it in the oven!
EDIT: This is still my go-to recipe. It's always a crowd pleaser, and it's easier to adjust the portion sizes. Making it for dinner again tonight.
If you don't like the base recipe, play around with it and find the balance of what you like best (different cheeses? My favorite is colby jack cheddar here).

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this mac & cheese and so did everyone else. I did make some adjustments based on comments off other reviews. First off this recipe is for 8oz box I had to double everything for my family. When I doubled the recipe I added 3/4 cup of milk.In stead of using all cottage cheese I added half ricotta cheese and I added 1 cup of mozzarella cheese and 3 cups sharp cheddar  this made it creamy and stringy.  I left everything else as the recipe called for. This made it perfect for everyone it has great flavor but if your idea of mac & cheese comes in a box then you are not going to like this. I will make this again and may add things like bacon or even put some tomatoes on top I didn't put any bread crumbs or crackers on top because that's not how we like our mac & cheese

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After having made bland, boring macaroni and cheese for years, I tried this recipe and it was outstanding!  My husband and I loved it!  And I followed the recipe very loosely.  I didn't include the topping (b/c I don't care for crumbs in pasta) and I didn't measure any ingredients, but included them all to taste. I admit... I only glanced over the ingredients and went out to buy the different cheeses.  I didn't even realize the original recipe didn't call for milk.  I have always added milk to mac & cheese, so I poured evaporated milk into the pasta and cheese mixture, with one beaten egg and I melted it for moments on a low fire (which eliminated the issue with the curds of cottage cheese (I hate curd texture too).  My cheeses blended smoothly and wow, are we impressed!  The recipe was easy and nothing short of delicious (even followed loosely).  Thank you much Chuck, for sharing.

I made a double batch, half as-written, half with the addition of ham, mushrooms and peas--both were tasty but I definitely prefer the version with ham and veggies.

Best mac & cheese recipe ever!  I made it even better by adding diced, leftover spiral ham, and adding some Loeb's Onion Crunch to the bread crumb mixture. I probably used more cheese than the recipe calls for, and it was a variety of what I had in the fridge - cheddar, monterey jack, colby, whatever.  I think the "secret" ingredients making this recipe awesome are the sour cream and cottage cheese. It was seriously off the charts, everyone loved it.

text:
When I first looked at this recipe, I scoffed at the dismissive negative review that said simply, "I'm sorry this was gross". Now that I've tried it, I'm starting to understand where beckyp382 is coming from.

There's a reason most macaroni and cheese recipes don't have sour cream and cottage cheese in them. Maybe if they were used as accents as opposed to 70% of the recipe, it would make more sense. This was soggy and not very tasty, except for the sour cream, which was all I could taste after a while. I had to stop mid-meal and eat something else.

text:
I have used this recipe (with less breadcrumbs and the addition of about 1/2 cup of milk) many times now and it's a crowd favorite!  It's being requested again for yet another event, superbowl mac and cheese this time!! And with the addition of milk to the cheese mixture, the leftover's are never dry and always nice and creamy.  One other tip, when people ask why it's so good and what the ingredients are, don't tell them it's made with cottage cheese.  For some reason that seems to scare some people and they make sour faces at the thought of it.  Just leave that as the "secret ingredient."

Ok, I hate to be a downer but we didn't care for this at all. 
All I can say is that the cheese did not adhere to the pasta at all.  Oddly the cheese mixture was kind of custardy and was separate from the elbows. The cheese didn't soak into nor coat the pasta.  I did blend up the cottage cheese a bit to removed the lumps from the cottage cheese, but I don't see how that would affect the end product.

text:
This is one of my favorite recipes I have ever gotten from this site.  I add a lot more cheese though.  I use a full package of spiral pasta (13oz) and add Mozz, and a bit of Mexican cheese.  I would say I add about 2 to two cups more of cheese.  I use all low fat everything and add a cup of low fat milk so the leftovers are not dry. I even made ti one time with Turkey Sausage and jalapenos and it was great. It tastes amazing also if you sub out all of the yellow cheeses for white ones and add pesto and chicken.  This is a fantastic   recipe to build off of.  I add something different each time.

text:
I made a few changes with the recipe as suggested by others.  I skipped the crumb topping (toped with a very thin layer of cheddar instead). Doubled the recipe, used low fat everything, added 1 cup milk, half an onion chopped, 1 tsp dry mustard and 1 tsp smoked paprika, plenty of fresh ground black pepper, used "cork screw" pasta and some cubed ham (just because I had it) YUM!!!  Next time, I will blend the cottage cheese to rid of the clumps and NOT salt the noodles and no salt to the recipe.  It had plenty of salt from the cheese and ham.

text:
I am giving this a 5 because I have adapted the recipe and made it even more fabulous. I make it about 3 times a year and everyone is always asking for more! I keep the recipe the same for the most part expect for these additions/subtractions - So given all of the suggestions I add 1/2 cup of milk (keeps it moist and not dried up), a jar of jalapeno cheese dip for an extra kick (it's not TOO spicy), a variety of cheeses (whatever's on sale or I go really fancy), and no bread crumbs (my personal preference).

text:
Amazing! New holiday favorite.  Splurge on good cheeses and lots of breadcrumbs!  Be patient while the cheese melts on low.  Rushing it will give you a grainy sauce.

text:
Neither my hubs or I cared for this at all (sorry!). Not only was this an odd take on our favorite comfort food, it was NOTHING like any mac & cheese we've ever had. This was not creamy, had an odd "tang" to it (prolly due to the sour cream) and looked terribly unappetizing on our plates. My cottage and cheddar cheeses never melted properly (hence the not so great texture / appearance). I expected a slightly creamy, custardy dish, but what I ended up with was FAR from it. NOTE: Traditional mac & cheese starts with a homemade cheese sauce. Flour and milk are slowly combined to form a roux and then a variety of cheeses are added to create a velvety smooth sauce. While this may be another way to enjoy a popular classic, It didn't do much for us. I guess I'm just a sucker for Mouse's macaroni & cheese (it seems more authentic, IMHO). Thanks anyways, MRSO. :-)

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This is hands down my all-time favorite macaroni and cheese recipe! I was hesitant to make it at first, because I had never before heard of cottage cheese or sour cream being used in mac and cheese...but, I'm so glad I gave it a shot. I found this recipe quite some time ago and I've made it many, many times since. I never change anything in the recipe -- it's perfect just the way it is. The only thing I "change" (not really a change, since it doesn't actually specify which to use) is my choice of bread crumbs. I use Italian style bread crumbs, not plain ones. The Italian flavor seems to give it a whole new layer of deliciousness. (The ONLY thing I would change, if I had to, would be the amount of bread crumbs. You could easily get away with using maybe a half a cup instead. But, I do love bread crumbs, so a full cup works for me!)

Sooo good, Chuck!  I usually make a more traditional and lower fat version but it's crappy compared to this recipe!  I followed the recipe exactly, except used ziti pasta and panko.  We had a bit extra parmy so added that with the breadcrumbs and butter!  It was rich and AMAZINGLY creamy!  Careful to add only 8oz of pasta...I almost used the whole box which was a pound.  We used good quality extra sharp chedder.  I'd like to try to make it lower in fat but it was so good and so worth the splurge!

text:
Love this!  I always use non fat sour cream and low fat cottage cheese to cut down on the richness some.  Add whatever seasonings you are in the mood for...this weekend I doubled the recipe and made two batches.  The first in a 9x13 with a mixture of seasoned pepper, garlic salt, cajun seasoning, and a pinch of cayenne mixed into the bread crumb mixture.  The second, no breadcrumbs and extra creamy (eyeball the milk...you won't go wrong) to make a velveeta like consistency for the kids.  Next time I will add curry, chicken, and a green veggie...yum!

text:
I havent reviewed on here in years, but I felt compelled to review this. I have never in my life intentionally ate cottage cheese, knowing its in there grosses me out. But, I took a risk after reading all the great reviews and made this....I'm not sorry!! It was delicious. It was easy to prepare, I had all the stuff already in my fridge (minus the cottage cheese) and it was ready in a snap! I only put half the amount of cottage cheese, because I was nervous I wouldnt like it if it tasted like it too much (which, it did not) and we didnt have a whole pack of shredded cheddar, so I put what we had (maybe 2ozs) and the rest in cheddar cheese slices I crumbled up, and I added two crumbled up pieces of American as well. Everthing else I did the same (but next time I will only use half the amount of bread crumbs....it was a bit much for me) we baked as directed and it was awesome, even my kids loved it. We ate and ate it and only ate half. So I saved the rest, and we'll heat it back up in its baking dish tomorrow and eat it with something else! It makes a large pan, my family of 5 only consumed half.

text:
This recipe turned out great.  We didn't end up adding the milk, but the end result wasn't as dry as some others claimed it to be (although I suppose all of that is based on preference).  The taste is great and it's very filling, but the stuff sits HEAVY in the stomach.  It took a few hours for me to feel alright again.  It'd be nice to lighten the recipe a bit, made by taking the bread crumb topping out and lessening the amount of cheddar cheese.  Next time we'll try adding some other ingredients.  The tomato soup that another reviewer suggested does sound like a good idea.

text:
Wow!  This dish went fast---all gone the first night!  I also modified the basic recipe some based upon what I hand on hand.  I substituted ricotta cheese for the cottage cheese.  I added about another cup's worth of cheese to the mix as well as one-half cup of whole milk.  We like Mrs. Dash seasoning, so I added lots of that as well.  For the topping, I used crushed salt and pepper kettle chips (instead of the bread crumbs)and added some extra cheese and some melted butter.  Kids loved the smell as it was cooking.  My teen-aged son had three helpings! Wish I had some for myself right now:)  Will definitely make this recipe again.  Thanks for sharing!

Made this on a recent camping trip thinking it would be a hit for both kids and adults alike.  Not that great.  Kids did not care for it and most of the adults couldn't get over the oily bread crumbs on top.  My suggestion to make this better is to incorporate a simple veggie mix to give it more nutrition and skip the bread crumbs on top.  Very salty made from original recipe but if you skip the breadcrumbs and do not add any salt it may help.
Review:
Rating:
4

2010-08-16T07:39:44.073

text:
I've tried many different recipes for mac and cheese, but I have to say this one is the best! While making it my husband was sceptical because of the cottage cheese and sour cream. He actually told me he wouldn't even try it. Its a good thing that he did because he was impressed and declared that I had to make this more often. I loved the topping but he wasn't so sure about it. I think it just depends on what you like. If you prefer topping like this, don't skip out. If you don't like it, still use this recipe but put a cheese blend on top.

text:
Surprisingly, the cottage cheese and cream cheese flavor didn't stand out like I thought it would.  In fact, based on the rave reviews, I was a little surprised by the lack of flavor.  It wasn't that cheesy at all...it was somewhat bland.  I followed the recipe; except, I followed the recommendation of the other reviewers and didn't use all of the bread crumbs.  I was able to thickly cover the casserole with about half of the bread crumbs.  I think next time I'll go for a cheesier mac and cheese recipe.

text:
ooooo...this is so yummy!!  I'm from the South and nothing up north compares to Southern mac and cheese!  Most of the Southern restaurants use cottage cheese and sour cream in theirs and this is the closest thing I've had!  It's just wonderful...my fiance and I are always trying out new mac and cheese recipes and this is by far our favorite.  We're huge fans of Panko breadcrumbs b/c they stay nice and crispy and crunchy when you back them, so that's what we use.  And we also love spicy food, so we always use pepper jack, or some variation of spicy cheese, as one of the cheeses.  This is a keeper :)

This was a wonderful variation on an all time favorite! I followed the reader suggestion of adding milk to combat any dryness and it worked beautifully! I also added a tsp of fresh cracked pepper and about a 1/4C Parmesan cheese to the breadcrumb topping and it gave the crust a delightful crunch! Crunchy topped is our family's favorite way to eat Mac-n-Cheese!

I didn't have any cottage cheese on hand so I replaced that with ricotta. When reading the reviews before making this, I couldn't understand how people could say it was dry with all the cheese involved! But, lo and behold, it was indeed dry. If I made it again, I would probably add milk to make it creamier. It was the kind of recipe where the first few bites were great, but... Also, if I make it again I'd definitely cut the amount of bread crumbs in half. Overall, I'm a bit disappointed.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my staple mac and cheese recipe - everyone asks for it. You need to add a half cup of milk and cut down on the bread crumb mixture by at least half. You can use low fat sour cream and cottage cheese, but you've got to use full fat cheddar cheese - not the 2%. I usually add some garlic powder and whatever other seasonings look good at the time. With these changes, I really don't know how anyone could NOT like this.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great adaptable creamy mac and cheese. I am sure this would be good just as it is.  Who would have know to use cottage cheese and sour cream?   Anyway I came across this recipe while looking for a recipe that would clean out my fridge.  I use up some other ingredients in my fridge, cut the amount of macaroni down to 6 oz added cooked bacon, sauteed onion and 1 jalopeno pepper, and some diced deli ham.  I also used swiss instead of cheddar.  It was very good.  I also season with chili pepper and a dash of hot pepper and dijon. the point of my review was that cottage cheese and sour cream are really the secret ingredients to good mac & cheese.

Tara

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I thought the basic recipe was great but I always switch and substitute in recipes. I used fat free half & half instead of adding milk like others had suggested. I also used the last bits of several different types of cheese that I had in the fridge; some manchego, gruyere, aged gouda & asadero plus a package of sharp Cheddar which made for extra creamy deliciousness. I processed the parmesan, sour cream and cottage cheese in the food processor with some kosher salt, wacky salt, seasoned salt, garlic & onion powder and a bit of tabasco and cajun seasoning for a little bit of zip. I also added a few teaspoons of leftover cream cheese :) On the top, I did a layer of cheddar cheese and I only had Italian breadcrumbs so I went with a crushed up mix of corn flakes, saltines & ritz crackers mixed with melted butter. It was even better with my many modifications but I am so glad for the idea of using sour cream and cottage cheese rather than the traditional ways with bechamel sauce or eggs. This is a much better base recipe to start from.

text:
I doubled the recipe for a big event.  I added an additional 8 oz bag of cheese to the dish (so 3 when I doubled it), and sprinkled panko breadcrumbs on top (without adding the butter).  I too used low fat cottage cheese, 2% cheese, and light sour cream.  I used spiral noodles versus elbow macaroni.  The dish was a hit!  This is also even better day 2.  It was thick so if you like fried mac and cheese, you could do that with this recipe.

text:
This recipe is AMAZING.  I used all low-fat cheeses, and actually had to substitute plain non-fat yogurt because I didn't have any sour cream, and it still tasted delicious.  Even my husband liked it, and he is a bona fide mac and cheese hater.  I also cut the recipe in half, but used almost 8 ounces of cavatappi pasta instead of 4 ounces elbow macaroni.  The ratio of sauce to pasta is great, and the flavour is wonderful.   This is my new go-to mac and cheese recipe.

Excellent flavor! This recipe is a favorite recipe in my house. It's both quick and easy.   My boyfriend requests it weekly. Both he and his bro LOVE it! I think it's delicious as well, but I'm lactose-intolerant and therefore all that cheese requires at least two Lactaid pills to digest. Anyway, thanks so much for this variation on mac and cheese!

I cut the amount of breadcrumbs to 2/3 cup.  I also added some strips of American cheese on top before the breadcrumbs to make it a little cheesier.  I will make this again.

text:
The flavor of this mac and cheese was very good, but the texture wasn't quite right. It was still a bit chunky from the cottage cheese, and a bit dry. I am going to add milk to the leftovers. Next time I will try baking it a little longer to let the cottage cheese melt, or maybe I will blend the cottage cheese in a food processor first. I like the tangy taste from the cottage cheese and sour cream. I used low-fat versions of both and regular sharp cheddar. I omitted the breadcrumbs and butter topping. Maybe the added butter would have helped the moisture problem.

text:
This is pretty good!  I've made it twice, now.  The first time was at my son's birthday party (at the doubled amount) and everyone raved over it.  The second time, I did it and it was a little better, probably because I made the breadcrumbs myself by taking 2 slices of Whitewheat and toasting them, then crumbled (loosely in chunks) into a bowl and tossed with melted butter to put over top.  Store-bought breadcrumbs are icky.  :)  This will probably be my go-to for mac and cheese; it's pretty easy.

I always look in allrecipes for new recipes before I look anywhere else. Almost, without fail the 4 and 5 star recipes have the the best I have found anywhere online. I tried this recipe tonight as it is cold here in Florida and we wanted some comfort food. I have to say, of all the recipes I have tried on allrecipes this is the most disappointing. The only things I changed after reading other reviews was: I added 1/2 cup milk to keep it moist and reduced the breadcrumbs to 1/4 cup. I found the flavor bland with the sour cream the most prominent flavor. I am still searching for the best mac and cheese and will keep looking. I will not make this again.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I will warn, this is NOT a traditional mac and cheese.  It's very tangy and the consistency is different.  That being said, it was GREAT!   I followed the recipe except I had a 12 oz block of sharp cheddar that I shredded by hand. I used probably a cup of shredded Parmesan, 1/4 cup of TGI Friday's bleu cheese dressing and 5-6 dashes of red Tabasco to give it a kick. You will definitely want to add about 1/2 cup of milk to keep it from being dry. I crumbled Ritz (veggie flavored) crackers on the top and sprayed it lightly with Pam instead of using butter.  Baked it for 30 minutes and it turned out beautifully.  I am a very amateur cook - the extent of my abilities is usually the microwave, so the fact that this turned out so well for me shows how easy it is.

DarkAngel

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Actually pretty good. I was doubtful about the cottage cheese, but it turned out well. I added a pinch of red pepper flakes for a kick, and my husband loved it. I halved the recipe and it still made quite a bit - my husband and I were eating leftovers for two days. This is not that gooey creamy mac and cheese but still very good. UPDATE 1/2009: I've made this four times now, and these are the changes I've made: for every one cup dry pasta I use 1/2 cup sour cream, 1/2 cup cottage cheese, 1/4 cup parmesan and 1 cup sharp shredded cheddar. I add about 1/2 tsp of crushed red pepper flakes, 1/4 tsp paprika, 1/4 tsp onion powder, 1/2 tsp dried parsley and 1/4 tsp ground black pepper. Once everything is mixed in the dish I pour about 1/2 cup of milk over the top - this results in a much creamier mac 'n' cheese. Top all with a sprinkling of shredded cheddar AND the butter/bread crumb mixture. The results are nothing short of fantastic; I will never order a gourmet mac and cheese from a restaurant again.

text:
I loved this recipe. It was easy to make and didnt require lots of prep work, which is great!  I used an 12 oz bag of noodles and found that to be a perfect amount. I added more cheddar cheese, and cut the cottage cheese to about 10 oz instead of 12. I also added 1/2 cup of Parmesan instead of 1/4, along with a little over 1/2 cup of milk for creaminess. 1 cup of bread crumbs is also way too much, you can probably cut it down about half.  Some reviewers said it was bland, but my husband LOVED it, so I think the additions of more cheese helped it create more flavor.

text:
This was really good!  I quadrupled the recipe so it was a really large batch.  I also made a mistake and added an extra 16oz sour cream by mistake and it still tasted good.  All the cheese did not melt inside though so the next time I make it, I will make the following changes--not rinse the pasta with cold water, instead, warm up the 1/2 c milk, mix it with the hot pasta, mix in the cheeses, so they will melt, the cottage cheesed, then the sour cream.  Also, cut the butter and bread crumbs in half, because it is too much.

This was a tasty recipe that was very easy to make "healthier."  I used fat-free cottage cheese and sour cream and low-fat shredded cheddar cheese.  It wasn't the "best-ever" mac & cheese I've had, but I will definitely make again because of it's low calories.  I may add some ground mustard seasoning to add some additional flavor as I have seen in other recipes.  Thanks for the easy, tasty, healthy dish!  My family liked this too!

Absolutely DELICIOUS!!  I hate the SITE of cottage cheese and was VERY hesitant to try this ... but I did because it made it fairly healthy :) I followed it to a tee except I didn't do the breadcrumbs. It was late and I was too lazy!  I sprinkled more of the sharp cheddar cheese on the top and OMG ... sooo good! I didn't tell my husband that it had cottage cheese and sour cream until he told me how DELICIOUS it was. He was amazed and had seconds.  I am eating it right now at my desk, ice cold ... it's like a macaroni pie!  No signs of cottage cheese and GREAT flavor. I used 'reduced-fat' sour cream.  Thanks for this one!  Making it for guests next week. Can't wait to tell them what's in it!   Oh, and I used a different small pasta instead of elbows because that's what I had ... rattoulli or something.

text:
This is by far the best mac and cheese I have ever eaten. I loved it and, more importantly, so did my whole family of picky eaters. I was nervous with the inclusion of cottage cheese, but the recipe is perfect as it is. I didn't change anything the first time I made it. The second time I made some changes to make it a bit more diet friendly. I simply substituted the lower fat versions of everything (low fat, NOT non-fat because then it is gross) and it was still delicious. I have to be careful to get enough protein and between the Barilla Plus pasta I used and the cottage cheese and other cheeses, this is a great dinner! Lots of protein and really not too much fat, with the substitutions. Any way you make it, this is delicious.!

text:
Much simpler than the "start with a white sauce" mac & cheese recipes, but not quite as cheesy tasting as those, either.  Also, a little on the salty side (probably the cottage cheese). I mixed all the dairy ingrediants in a bowl and added milk (1/2 cup?) before mixing it with the pasta.  The cottage cheese curds were really obvious the next day when I reheated the leftovers, but the flavor was still pretty good.

I made this for the first time tonight. My 4 year old love mac & cheese and i've been searching for one to make for him. This was also the first time i've ever made it from scratch and not form a box. It was very yummy. It wasn't dry like some said. Although i did added a little light cream (i didn't have milk) just incase. I also only added a small amount of crumbs on top (used panko) Don't really wanna overload it :) Other then that i totally followed the recipe. My son ate it right up. It is definitely worth remaking. I'm even thinking of bringing it to my cousin's who will be hosting our family Thanksgiving dinner this year :)  EDIT.... Made this again but instead of normal mac i used the whole wheat type (hubby is trying to force better eating habits) Anyway, it came out just as good. You can't even tell it's whole wheat pasta. But the 2nd time around i forgot to add the Parmesan. I had no idea until after we finished it so it really didn't need it. Still just as good. And this dish i think actually taste better as leftovers :)

text:
Whoever Chuck is, this recipe is fabulous. I don't really care for mac and cheese (too orange), but hubby likes it. The catch he doesn't do cottage cheese or sour cream. Told him I was making mac & cheese, he said are you sure?? I said, of course. He went to the store while the elbows were cooking. I put the rest of the ingredients  together, mixed well. Tossed in the elbows and put it into the oven by the time he returned. Store is 5 minutes away. He ate it and asked for seconds. HURRAY!!!! Had extra elbows and more cheeses and sour cream so I'll put it together and froze for another day. Thanks again.

text:
I made a few changes to this recipe to make it healthier, which is maybe why it didn't taste that great.  I used whole wheat pasta, 1/2 fat free cheddar cheese, 1/2 2% cheddar cheese, fat free cottage cheese, and lowfat sour cream.  I also added tomatoes, asparagus, and brocolli.  I also added some garlic powder, and the taste was still just kind of bla.  If I hadn't of added the vegetables, I think it would have been tasteless.  Though, that may be because I used all low fat ingredients.  I will not make it again as I always cook low fat.  I was really hopeful of this recipe from all the reviews, but it just wasn't for me.

text:
My three children are CRAZY about Mac and Cheese!  My five year old helped me make it and she was so excited.  She tasted it when it was done and said, "Mommy, it needs more flavor."  I completely agree.  The flavor of this dish is very mild.  It's not bad in any way, just bland.  I don't particularly like Mac and Cheese that tastes like biting into a spoon of pure cheese.  This dish went in the opposite direction though.  None of my kids ate an entire serving.  I only used half of the butter/bread crumb mixture and it was still too much for our liking.  Also, I agree that the recipe definitely needs milk.  I thought I added quite a bit of milk but it was still on the dry side.  I will be looking for a cheesier and moister mac and cheese recipe.

text:
I have to admit, after reading many of the reviews I was expecting the mac of all mac and cheeses, but for me it just wasn't there. I'm not saying the recipe was bad, it just wasn't mouth watering and it certainly didn't get me excited. Part of the reason may be because I'm not really a mac and cheese type of girl, but I found that the whole thing wasn't too flavorful or particularly memorable. Perhaps I should have added those bread crumbs and butter which I skipped because they just didn't appeal to me. Everything else I kept exact (oh except I used 16oz of pasta instead of 8oz and I couldn't imagine using less, was that a typo??) I did however find it tasted better after reheating which was slightly odd, but good because most mac and cheese is horrid after reheating. All in all, it's a decent recipe, just not worth writing home about and I may hesitate before making it again. If you are a mac and cheese lover, give it a go, maybe it's just me.

Display Name:
Susancooks

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I give this 5 stars even though I changed some things. Everyone has different tastes so I consider recipes to be a base to start with.  I sauteed pancetta, onions, and mushrooms, and also added some fresh sweet peas.  I cut the sour cream by 1/4 and added dry mustard and Thai chili powder for some punch.  I also added 1/4 cup of half and half, saving the rest to use when reheating.  I used Japanese panko for the breadcrumbs as a poster suggested and added the fresh grated parmesan to that.  That gave a nice crunchy crust but was a bit lighter than breadcrumbs and butter.  I would add that it is far easier to mix all of the wet ingredients, spices, and cheese in a large bowl before adding to the pasta and any additions.  That way you get a more consistent mixture.  My husband and I both grew up on baked homemade mac and cheese so this was right up our alley.  Delicious!  It IS rich but we used it as a side dish with a large green salad and lemon sorbet for dessert.  I will definitely make this again.

text:
Best homemade mac and cheese I've ever had. I think I've finally found a recipe I'll use regularly.  Was out of normal breadcrumbs so I used panko, Japanese style breadcrumbs and was very satisfied with the results. To keep all the cheeses from separating, as a reviewer mentioned having problems with, I put all the ingredients that would be mixed in with the pasta through the food processor first and added a little bit of milk.  I even loved it day old and cold.

text:
This is an excellent mac & cheese!  I added in a little onion powder -  and as others suggested some milk to make more creamier (1/2 & 1/2 would be ideal!)  If you prefer "less homemade" you could substitute some of the sharp cheddar for velveta cheese.  I was low on parmesan cheese, so I threw in a little italian cheese blend.  If feeding a crowd you will want to double the recipe - this stuff goes fast!

text:
This is hands down the best Mac and Cheese I've ever had. I found this recipe while trying to find food for my daughter first birthday party. I wanted kid friendly food that adults would still enjoy. This was perfect. Everyone at the party went on and on about it. I didn't do the bread crumbs topping as I was feeding 70 people so I was refilling constantly. I didn't tell anyone about the cottage cheese or sour cream until the end of the party. One friend who is one of those adults that still eats like a 5 yr old, kept saying how good it was and told his wife to get the recipe. As I was telling her his face just dropped and she started laughing and said he hates cottage cheese and sour cream. LOL! I used low fat cottage cheese and sour cream to save a few calories and it still turned out great. I make this all the time now and my whole family loves it.

text:
Yum.  So good.  My changes were to saute a minced onion in olive oil, add chopped mushrooms and a package of cooked frozen peas.  After macaroni has cooked, pour in back into the large pot it cooked in and add ALL the ingredient to it along with a 1/2 cup of milk.  Stir well then pour into baking dish.  Instead of the peas, broccoli would also be terrific.  Enjoy!

This recipe is the best combination of the dry Mom's old fashioned mac n' cheese, and the creamy mac n' cheese of current.  This recipe is excellent, and sure to please everyone. Very good mac & cheese.  I do admit I had to sub some stuff because I didn't have it on hand but even with the substitutions it was great.  I used 4 oz sharp cheddar, 4 oz velveeta, no cottage cheese (didn't have any) but used 1 egg instead, and used ritz crackers (about 10) on top. Plus I food processed all the cheeses with the egg and sour cream (great idea whoever said that!)  De-Lish!

text:
My first attempt at Mac and Cheese, and it was  good! I added chopped ham and peas, and used italian bread crumbs. Also used light cheddar, fat free cottage cheese and fat free sour cream to make it a bit healthier. And half a cup of skim milk. Also, I minced half a cup of onion, and used 3 cloves of garlic, minced. Didn't add a touch of salt. With the ham and cheese, and the seasoned bread crumbs, it didn't need it at all.

This is my first time at mac n cheese and already I found a keeper. I agree with some of the other reviews about it not being creamy enough and that the bread crumb mixture was very dry. text:
Well first off, I'm not very exposed to macaroni and cheese, so I decided to use this recipe. It wasn't enough to fill the 9x13 baking dish, so I had to add one more cup of macaroni at the last minute. To make sure that the recipe wouldn't be dry afterwards, I added one cup of milk, as well as some mozzarella cheese. 

It looked and tasted great, for about 5 minutes. When I came back later on for just a bit, the cheese and macaroni were all clumped up (i.e, some parts were really salty and cheesy, while some parts had NO cheese and NO taste), it was too dry, and WAY too hard. I was hoping for some nice, stretchy and soft macaroni and cheese, but sadly, this wasn't it.

text:
I'm  new to this site but find many similarities of common recipes I've tried - Macaroni and cheese, another family favorite! Ok,so try this recipe my omitting the cottage cheese, replacing w/jar of double cheddar cheese sauce, blend w/sour cream, 1/2 stick butter,1/2 c. buttermilk and cooked macaroni. Season w/white pepper and dash of seasoned salt then multi-layer mixture w/parmesan and 4-6 oz. grated cheddar cheeses. 

p/s GodivaGirl - you are all that! I love beautiful foods and you have the pictures to prove it!

text:
Holy cheesiness!  Yummy, yum.  I made this as directed but did add 1/2 cup of milk as per other reviews.  It was EXTREMELY creamy and at first a bit liquidy though as it cooled it thickened.

I think next time i might try just 1/4 cup milk and see how that went but it was certainly ok with 1/2 cup, it just made me wonder if the milk was even necessary.

I used 1% cottage cheese, fat free sour cream, and 2% old cheddar and it was so yummy.  All of us loved in, even my 8 yo son who doesn't usually like mac n' cheese much at his up.  We will definitely be having this again.

I don't know if it's fair to really rate this recipe because I did alter it.  I didn't have any cottage cheese so I omitted that and added some slices of american cheese to the top of the noodles halfway through baking.  My 7 year old LOVED it and had 2 helpings, but my 4 year old and 2 year old wanted no part of it.  I think the cheddar was too sharp for them. I also added some milk which made it creamier.  And I skipped the breadcrumbs.   I think this is a great recipe for adults to "fancy up" mac n cheese, but if you have picky kids, try another recipe.

I really wanted this to be fantastic, but not a single person wanted to eat it after the first bite and I ended up making peanut butter sandwiches for everyone to eat. I followed the directions exactly, but found the taste to be incredibly bland. I even tried to add some flavor after the first bite, and still ended up throwing the whole dish out. I think I will stick with another baked mac on this site.

text:
I followed the advice of others here - only used about 1/4 c of Italian seasoned bread crumbs on top (though I could do without), 1/4 c of milk, and processed the cottage cheese.  Overall, I felt it needed - something.  

So, I used a parmesian/mozz. mix cheese and half a small jar of nacho cheese dip (sharp cheddar with hot peppers/spices) for a kick.  I also used more pasta than the recipe called for - closer to 12 oz.  

Pretty good change of pace.

text:
I'm giving this 5 stars even though I used this recipe more as a guide.  I did zero measuring, and just went with what looked right.  I used seashell pasta with peas (instead of the macaroni) and just barely sifted some bread crumbs on top.  I omitted the butter as this seems to have enough fat/calories packed in.  It was fabulous.  I wouldn't have come up with it on my own, but am so glad to have stumbled across it.  The kids loved it, too.  Will definitely do this again and again.

country:
None
text:
This was VERY VERY good. I was really surprised just how good it was. I used Italian seasoned breadcrumbs on top, but I recommend that you use your favorite flavor because the dish takes on a lot of the breadcrumb flavor. When you dish out a spoonful onto your plate the breadcrumbs, being there is a lot, (1 cup) fall onto the macaroni mixture and coating the macaroni even more. I kind of stirred it into the macaroni noodles to give it that extra nice coating.  I used the large macaroni. This is so easy to make and well worth it. Try it, you wont be disappointed.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/3052.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This mac and cheese was cheap, easy and delicious.  I would suggest shredding your own 8-10 oz block of sharp cheddar for better flavor, I also added a tsp brown mustard and some dashes of hot sauce for flavor.  My only change will be omitting the butter from the topping.  Rather than mixing it into the breadcrumbs I had cut the butter into small cubes and dotted the casserole with it which lead to it being greasier than necessary.  Frankly I don't think this needs any butter as there's plenty of dairy to begin with.  Very good though.

text:
I can't beleive the simple yet awesome taste this recipe makes. I have made a few changes including nuking it to melt the cheese and using ricotta cheese in place of cottage cheese. I also crumble crackers instead of bread crumbs. I've made this for picnics, parties and just because meals without problems. It's too good to keep to myself. Thanks Chuck where ever you are!

text:
I really enjoyed this recipe. It makes a slightly different style of mac-n-cheese so it is nice for a change of pace. My husband prefers a creamier version so I take turns making this recipe and another. I have used cracker crumbs, cornflake crumbs and even potato chips crumbs as topping and they are all good.
